contentrichtext.text: In [[Egyptian mythology]], '''Ha''' was a god of the [[desert]]s to the west of [[Egypt]]. He was associated with the [[underworld]] ([[Duat]]) and pictured as a man wearing the symbol for desert hills on his head. Ha was said to protect Egypt from enemies such as invading tribes from Libya.<ref>Wilkinson, Richard H. (2003). ''The Complete Gods and Goddesses of Ancient Egypt''. Thames & Hudson. p. 106</ref> The dinosaur ''[[Hagryphus]]'' ("Ha's griffin") was named after Ha; it was discovered in Utah and Ha's association with "the Western Desert" was carried over to the New World.<ref>Zanno, L. E. and Sampson, S. D. 2005. A new oviraptorosaur (Theropoda; Maniraptora) from the Late Cretaceous (Campanian) of Utah. Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology 25 (4):897â€“904, December 2005</ref> == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Egyptian gods]] [[Category:Egyptian mythology]] [[Category:Nature gods]] [[Category:Underworld gods]] {{Egyptian-myth-stub}}
